Mine: World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis

If anything I'm trying to spur some discussion on the itemization of the Lich King weapons, and on expertise in particular which seems to be an area of discussion that hasn't had enough attention paid to. #2459SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Complicated
Originally Posted by grosdawson
hello there, what do you think about taking 2p of the tanking T10 set for fights when DnD is on top of use (or trash mobs)

+20% on DnD, do you think that it would compensate the lost of dps stats ?
i'll suggest to take legs and hands for expertise and hit on them

i'm pretty sure none dk dps had focused on that to test it so...
or maybe it will be always better to stay on 4pT9 for heavy aoe fights

what do you think ?
This isn't so hard to calculate, let's standardize using Anub parses with none of the mentioned set bonusses in action:
Ability
Death & Decay
Blood Plague
Frost Fever
avg %
~20%
~15%
~15%
Now before comparing stats on the tiers themselves lets calculate the value in an AoE fight:

4pc T10: 100% x 3% = 3% total damage increase

2pc Tank T10: 20% x 20% = 4% total damage increase

4pc T9: 15% x ~50% = 7,5% total damage increase


Conclusion: T10[277] > T9[258] > T9[245] > T10[264] > T10[251] > T10Tank

If anyone's interested in going more in depth about stats, feel free to question my math.
Last edited by Complicated : 02/04/10 at 5:06 AM. Reason: Looks like LK and possibly HM's may be AoE heavy.
#2460SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3h311ion
Originally Posted by Complicated

Also it's pretty safe to say there won't be such an AoE heavy fight like Anub in ICC, favouring T10 even more.
Lich King is an extremely AoE heavy fight. Sindragosa is as well to some extent, lots of Frost Tombs to AoE until the 30% phase hits.
#2461SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Derps
Hello gentlemen.

My topic today does not deal with anything i've read on these forums before, but perhaps has been addressed prior...I could not find any information on the subject so if someone more knowledgeable knows the answer, I'd be happy to hear it.

Comparing 2 parses, the first is mine and the second is the other unholy dk in my guild, we have similar gear but that really has nothing to do with it. Basically my question concerns the gargoyle and how it chooses rather to melee or gargoyle strike and if you can prevent it from melee'ing.

WoW Meters Online - Combatlog Replay

WoW Meters Online - Combatlog Replay

As you can see, on this particular fight - 25m Saurfang - his gargoyle did 4 more gargoyle strikes and melee'd 4 less times, for ~19000 more overall damage. Now granted this isn't a huge difference, but it is a difference nonetheless and I play this game on min/max mode. Also note for some reason my gargoyle lasted for 26 seconds rather than 30.

*edit* After posting this I also went to a dummy in SW and ran my regular rotation on it, gargoyle didn't melee a single time.

| Sigil | Virulence
| RuneEnchant | FallenCrusader /
| Pet Calculation | True

Going by this, ARP is worth more than str for me. Am i doing something wrong?
The thing about ARP is that it scales heavily with how much you already have. Looking at your setup, you are currently gemmed primarily into ARP already, which could possibly be why it is giving you such a high EP value. EDIT: just ran the sim for myself, I think you may have something set wrong in your EP sim, I just ran the sim with your current stats from armory and got:

EP AttackPower | 1 (0.68 DPS/per AP)
EP Strength | 2.94
EP Agility | 1.32
EP CritRating | 1.88
EP HasteEstimated | 0.03
EP HasteRating1 | 2.71
EP ArmorPenetrationRating | 2.35
EP ExpertiseRating | 2.12
BeforeMeleeHitCap<8% | 1.68
EP SpellHitRating | 0
EP WeaponDPS | 7.21
EP WeaponSpeed | 338.24
I ran a quick sim just to get a general idea, since I'm on a work computer at the moment, some values may be slightly off, I'll run a full length one in a min.

I did a DPS sim as well to see if the results match up, with your current ARP gem setup it is showing:
DPS| 9289
Total Damage| 334.41m | in 10h

I replaced all your ARP gems with STR gems and got:
DPS| 9594
Total Damage| 345.39m | in 10h

It could possibly be an incorrect rotation setting in your sim that is giving you the incorrect numbers, or the simulation time you are using is throwing off the numbers (if it is too short).
Last edited by Unholymoon : 02/04/10 at 12:37 PM.

To add to the Gargoyle discussion:

I'm not going to post 10 or so links here, though you can browse basically all my logs through the guild calendar on WMO Draconic Savant on WMO I should be in just about every log there.

There's numerous cases of gargoyle values being all over the place. Here's the best two examples:

WoW Meters Online - Combatlog Replay - 24 ranged attacks, 2 melee.

WoW Meters Online - Combatlog Replay - 16 ranged attacks, 8 melee.

Around a 40k damage difference. Pretty damn significant really, especially when you consider the overall damage done by things like Unholy Blight, BCB, or Blood Strike for the sake of comparisons.
#2466SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
As I've experienced the gargoyle chooses to melee for the first few seconds after it's been summon if it spawns right on top of the boss. So basically the only way to avoid this is to summon while the boss is being moved as the gargoyle will spawn about where the boss was during summoning. Of course, that's not always possible and I guess it's probably a DPS loss to wait until the boss is being moved instead of summoning with trinket / runeforge procs up.

#2470SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Komiya

#2471SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pulz
Originally Posted by Jussonice
One thing I noted was on the Festergut fight my Gargoyle did 26 melee hits. Where as on Deathbringer he did only 3. Very odd as I never really payed attention to this before.

I noticed this a few week back and spent a few hours trying to figure out how to avoid this but it's quite tricky as it turns out. Size of the hitbox seem to affect it.

On a small hitbox like the target dummy or Saurfang it will mostly be a none issue. You can now and then have it get another cast of by summoning it close to the center of the hitbox, opposed to max melee range. Summoning at this position would, in my tests, 90% of the time lead to the gargoyle melee hitting just as it spawned and then fly out to range. If I summoned to far out and it would fly in, melee and then fly out, losing one cast (with the haste I had during testing). Only way to avoid the melee hit at all on a small hitbox had me run far far (15 or so yard) out of melee losing 1+ autoattacks or more.

On larger hitboxes it gets even tricker since the gargoyle seem to focus on the center of the hitbox and never fly far enough out to not be able to melee it.

I have given up trying to get the perfect gargoyle summoning of on all but Prof. Putricide pull. We usually pull him a short distance from the table where I get to start hitting him until he spawns the first puddles. As the tank moves him away from these is the perfect time to summon and have it only cast without getting melee hits.
(Link to last two raids 10m 25m reports, 2 gargoyles, one at start with 0 melees and one during BL burn with 1 melee)

Originally Posted by Moaradin

I too am curious about this. I had spec'd into reaping and was using a 2p T10 and 2P T9 setup. My melee dmg was higher then my SS dmg on Saurfang. WoW Meters Online - Combatlog Replay

My thinking is that even with 2P T10, it doesn't become worthwhile to spec into reaping until you've reached a certain ArmPen rating. (For the above log I believe I was at about 24% armpen) What the magic armpen number is when it becomes worth while to switch from 4p T9 into 2P T10 and reaping I don't know. Apologies, I know assumptions are frowned upon here. Doing the math is something I don't even pretend to know how to approach.

Any guidance, or realignment in thinking, would be greatly appreciated here.

Couple more notes, I'm on a mac so running something like DK gear optimizer isn't an option. My current armory does not reflect what I was wearing during the above log.
#2473SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Malkiah
Originally Posted by rhackin
Is there any reason that Improved Icy Talons doesn't refresh when you refresh diseases using GoD?
because the tooltip is somewhat deceptive and IIT (and subsequent talents) actually fires from IT and not FF.
#2474SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Lugz
Was wondering if anyone has noticed a dps drop from Bryntroll procs? There's some rumblings on the dps/dk forums on the wow site about the proc almost being cut in half. Has any experienced this yet? I'm reluctant to trust these reports, treating them the same as "Onyxia Deep Breaths More". And since there are no comments on here yet, I'm figuring it's just people getting bad RNG.

But, Nibelung also got nerfed, so I'm wondering if Bryntroll got mixed up in there as well. Just throwing this out there, so maybe some people can look over their logs, and see if they notice a significant drop in procs.

I just read about it this morning, so the only thing I've been able to do is a target dummy test, where it was 3.5% of my damage. But, target dummies are inaccurate, so I"m not taking those numbers to heart

edit: Just did a second target dummy test, this time around 10 minutes long. The Drain Life proc made up about 5.6% of my dps, which is typical. In my opinion, I think people are citing bad rng as a nerf. But it might be something we keep our eyes open for.
Last edited by Lugz : 02/04/10 at 4:47 PM.
#2475SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lucid
Originally Posted by Lugz
Was wondering if anyone has noticed a dps drop from Bryntroll procs? There's some rumblings on the dps/dk forums on the wow site about the proc almost being cut in half. Has any experienced this yet? I'm reluctant to trust these reports, treating them the same as "Onyxia Deep Breaths More". And since there are no comments on here yet, I'm figuring it's just people getting bad RNG.

But, Nibelung also got nerfed, so I'm wondering if Bryntroll got mixed up in there as well. Just throwing this out there, so maybe some people can look over their logs, and see if they notice a significant drop in procs.

I just read about it this morning, so the only thing I've been able to do is a target dummy test, where it was 3.5% of my damage. But, target dummies are inaccurate, so I"m not taking those numbers to heart

edit: Just did a second target dummy test, this time around 10 minutes long. The Drain Life proc made up about 5.6% of my dps, which is typical. In my opinion, I think people are citing bad rng as a nerf. But it might be something we keep our eyes open for.
I noticed this too and after about 5 minutes of testing I believe that it can at least be attributed to no longer proccing off disease application or refresh. Before 3.3.2 but after the hotfix that took away scourge strike double procs it was most definitely proccing off disease application/refresh. This is no longer the case. As for the actual PPM, I have no idea if it's been changed.
#2476SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Illandras
Originally Posted by Lugz
edit: Just did a second target dummy test, this time around 10 minutes long. The Drain Life proc made up about 5.6% of my dps, which is typical. In my opinion, I think people are citing bad rng as a nerf. But it might be something we keep our eyes open for.
You can't test Bryntroll accurately on a dummy since the proc is flat, and not affected by buffs in a raid, therefore it will be a higher % of your total damage done, what you can test though, is the procrate.
#2477SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lugz
Well, I'm testing right now on a target dummy to see if it procs off of diseases. I'm not sure the best way to do this, so I've just been casting PS and IT. I did notice on one test, that Plague Strike appeared to proc drain life. There was no melee swing before the proc, the only thing that could've proc'd it was PS.

Is there a better way that I can test the proc rate?

-edit: And even if Bryntroll is a flat proc, wouldn't buffs like Bloodlust/Windfury increase the overall damage from the proc, due to more swings?
#2478SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lucid
Originally Posted by Lugz
Well, I'm testing right now on a target dummy to see if it procs off of diseases. I'm not sure the best way to do this, so I've just been casting PS and IT. I did notice on one test, that Plague Strike appeared to proc drain life. There was no melee swing before the proc, the only thing that could've proc'd it was PS.

Is there a better way that I can test the proc rate?

-edit: And even if Bryntroll is a flat proc, wouldn't buffs like Bloodlust/Windfury increase the overall damage from the proc, due to more swings?
I tested two ways (for the disease application). One was to use endless winter and spam chains of ice. The other was to use icy touch about a second after a melee swing. So this really only tests frost fever, but I would assume if frost fever doesn't work, neither would blood plague. This doesn't mean that plague strike would no longer work, but it would mean that you no longer get 2 chances from plague strike via the strike+disease. It seems like blizz just wants it to proc off physical attacks.

#2481SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Lugz
Well, that's interesting. Guess I'll have to see tonight in ICC if it makes a noticeable difference in dps. If these changes stay, then I assume this is Blizzards way of forcing us to move on from proc weapons like Nibelung and Bryntroll. Oh well, suppose this just gives me more incentive to farm 25 saronites now.

But honestly, I don't think this will have a substantial effect on our dps due to the relatively low number of times were cast our diseases during a fight. Not sure how I would go about calculating that, but based on what i think was removed from possible procs, here is what we lost:

In any given minute of where we apply disease every 20 seconds, we lost 3 chances from BP application, 3 chances from IT, and 3 chances from FF application. So in total, 9 procs per minute. However, at only a ~11% proc rate, we're only looking at an average of 1-2 procs lost per minute. Please correct me if I'm wrong, which would not surprise me in the slightest.

edit- Okay, did a test just now to see if Plague Strike would proc Drain Life, and it does appear as though it does. All I did was use PS, and when I saw Drain Life proc, I checked my combat log. Usually, it was a melee attack that proc'd it, but there were several instances where the PS itself would proc the Drain Life. So, the application of BP, IT, and the application of FF have been removed. Meh

edit 2-@Archnoel: I did the same test, with no Drain Life procs. However, I'm still wondering if DL would proc anyway if we're positioning ourselves so that melee strikes can't occur. Honestly, I've never paid much attention to the actual behavior of the proc. Without me knowing if it follows the same melee rules, i.e. facing, positioning, etc, I'm still unsure as to whether or not this proc removal is real or not. But, without a doubt, at least the strike portion of PS proc's it.

#2482SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Buffie
Originally Posted by Roujin
I too am curious about this. I had spec'd into reaping and was using a 2p T10 and 2P T9 setup. My melee dmg was higher then my SS dmg on Saurfang. WoW Meters Online - Combatlog Replay

My thinking is that even with 2P T10, it doesn't become worthwhile to spec into reaping until you've reached a certain ArmPen rating. (For the above log I believe I was at about 24% armpen) What the magic armpen number is when it becomes worth while to switch from 4p T9 into 2P T10 and reaping I don't know. Apologies, I know assumptions are frowned upon here. Doing the math is something I don't even pretend to know how to approach.

Any guidance, or realignment in thinking, would be greatly appreciated here.

Couple more notes, I'm on a mac so running something like DK gear optimizer isn't an option. My current armory does not reflect what I was wearing during the above log.
As you seem to know, the real way to know is to sim & find out for sure. The point at which to swap to reaping won't be something so simple as "get X ArP, then go reaping." The easiest way to explain it is when the damage of 1 SS is far enough ahead of 2xBS to make up for the points you'll be moving to pick up reaping. This is a pretty simplified litmus test, since there are a few other factors such as the extra gcd per rotation (for example; reaping will gain value if you're getting a lot of RP from revitalize), so this isn't the ultimate solution, but it's a way to get a rough idea.

#2485SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by Nahela
That really isn't consistent with my data. There was no movement involved at all on those Saurfang logs.
I was saying that there is usually no meleeing if the boss is moved during summoning (e.g. Putricide). If the boss is not moved, it's as I get it pretty random if and how much it melees. So, it is consistent. It would be inconsistent if the boss was moved during summoning and there is still meleeing.

#2487SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Glutton
It seems like there was a universal nerf to procs from debuffs. Casters are also noticing the change with Nibelung and I have personally tested it with Bryntroll and Retribution debuffs.
#2488SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Yotka
GoSS testing following the lead from another DK - gave practical results well above other glyphs for UH.

Basically, without a GoD, if you SS*3 then pestilence - you bypass the 9 second rule of GoSS - which allows you to disease roll and never have to re-apply PS/IT unless the situation demands for it.

Though, there is a problem of importance when it comes to pure single target fights... the pestilence at least needs to touch another mob.

Basically, the game is thinking that the diseases applied to the other mobs via pestilence are new un-GoSSed ones - this is applying to your primary target without even needing to switch targets.

If other Death Knights find similar results, it's going to be changing a lot of things where glyphs are concerned.
#2489SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Sulika
Originally Posted by Roujin
I too am curious about this. I had spec'd into reaping and was using a 2p T10 and 2P T9 setup. My melee dmg was higher then my SS dmg on Saurfang. WoW Meters Online - Combatlog Replay

My thinking is that even with 2P T10, it doesn't become worthwhile to spec into reaping until you've reached a certain ArmPen rating. (For the above log I believe I was at about 24% armpen) What the magic armpen number is when it becomes worth while to switch from 4p T9 into 2P T10 and reaping I don't know. Apologies, I know assumptions are frowned upon here. Doing the math is something I don't even pretend to know how to approach.

Any guidance, or realignment in thinking, would be greatly appreciated here.

Couple more notes, I'm on a mac so running something like DK gear optimizer isn't an option. My current armory does not reflect what I was wearing during the above log.
Just looking at your logs you have 44 scourge strikes used and 48 blood strikes used. In a normal rotation your SS-BS ratio should be 2:1. Yours is more like 1:1. In an ideal rotation, you would have 54 SS and 28 BS for the same amount of runes. This would take SS from being 17.4% of your damage to being about 21.3% of your damage which would put SS above melee in your overall damage done.

So probably you are sometimes using BS-BS on the second half of your roation instead of SS which will have an associated reduction in SS as a percentage of your overall damage and with it an associated reduction in the relative value of the 2-piece T10 bonus. This is the area where theory collides with practice, a simulator never messes up its rotation whereas real people do and in some fights maintaining a perfect rotation just isn't practical.
Last edited by Sulika : 02/05/10 at 5:53 AM.
#2490SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Alyse
Originally Posted by Yotka
GoSS testing following the lead from another DK - gave practical results well above other glyphs for UH.

Basically, without a GoD, if you SS*3 then pestilence - you bypass the 9 second rule of GoSS - which allows you to disease roll and never have to re-apply PS/IT unless the situation demands for it.

Though, there is a problem of importance when it comes to pure single target fights... the pestilence at least needs to touch another mob.

Basically, the game is thinking that the diseases applied to the other mobs via pestilence are new un-GoSSed ones - this is applying to your primary target without even needing to switch targets.

If other Death Knights find similar results, it's going to be changing a lot of things where glyphs are concerned.
While this method does work, you will still have to refresh your diseases at some point. In a typical 20 second rotation, you would need to SS at least 7 times in order to never have your diseases fall off. This also means you would have to pestilence at least 2 times, occasionally 3, in order to achieve the extended duration on your diseases for each SS. This is obviously impossible, barring using ERW to achieve this rotation.
#2491SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Nekali
Since you need to Pestilence anyways to abuse GoSS in this way, there is not way this could be better then just using GoD, unless you can roll disease coefficients with GoSS in this way.
Some tissue math, assuming it does roll coefficients:
To maintain it you would need 1pest every three SS though, making a reaping spec unpractical. When going Pest->BS->SS->SS->Dump->Repeat you lose 4s worth of diseases every 10s on average, requiring you to hard refresh eventually. Ignoring that you would need to hard refresh, you trade 1BS/20s vs the standard GoD spec. Going by my numbers from the last Festergut kill, my diseaes tick for an average of 2150/1750 with a fully buffed maximum of 2700/2300. So assuming Ideal conditions where you can maintain fully buffed diseases this is a 1100dmg gain per 3s or 7333dmg per 20s which is about 1.3k more then my average blood strike. An DPS increase of ~65dps under ideal conditions over a GoD spec, which is worse then the GoDD spec.
However in an AoE heavy situation and using 4t9 this might pull ahead of GoD, if GoSS rolls coefficients, I will definetly test this on Anub'Arak this week.
Last edited by Nekali : 02/05/10 at 9:40 AM.

Others have reported this because they're either simming wrong or made an error in entering stats, Armor Pen. should never scale above Strength for Unholy Death Knights untill full 277 gear and then only on single target which makes it pretty much obsolete.

Btw: you might want to sim with another Sigil like Virulence or Hanged Man.

#2501SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Nekali
Originally Posted by Yotka
GoSS does roll coefficients - which is the entire point for AoE. Switching targets and applying SS's to lengthen the disease rolling might be slightly complicated in a real situation though.
I can confirm that GoSS rolls coefficients and that Pestilence resets the GoSS counter, if secondary targets are hit. However in a true AE situation (like Anub) there won't be a lot of runes available for SS since you also DnD. The only encounter that springs to my mind where you permanently have a secondary target, but don't want to DnD is Twins.

#2504SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Weidekuh
I just need confirmation for my math.

Regarding future hardmodes with lot of movement, where reaching my target faster or escaping damage can be critical. I was thinking about dropping 2 points in dark conviction and picking up improved unholy presence.

I lose 2% crit which equals approx. 44 critrating. 44 critrating are around 88 Statweights at my ilvl.
88 AP are ~ 58 DPS.

So i lose around 58 DPS on fights where i don't have to move.
But i reach every Mob i have to switch an run to 16% faster. That would be for Lady Deathwhisper, Rotface, Prof. Putricide, Blood Princes, Queen, Valithria (maybe even marrowgar in hardmodes).

I took the statconversions from this thread for ~ilvl 245-250.
Last edited by Weidekuh : 02/07/10 at 10:16 AM.
#2505SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sulika
Originally Posted by Weidekuh
I just need confirmation for my math.

Regarding future hardmodes with lot of movement, where reaching my target faster or escaping damage can be critical. I was thinking about dropping 2 points in dark conviction and picking up improved unholy presence.

I lose 2% crit which equals approx. 44 critrating. 44 critrating are around 88 Statweights at my ilvl.
88 AP are ~ 58 DPS.

So i lose around 58 DPS on fights where i don't have to move.
But i reach every Mob i have to switch an run to 16% faster. That would be for Lady Deathwhisper, Rotface, Prof. Putricide, Blood Princes, Queen, Valithria (maybe even marrowgar in hardmodes).

I took the statconversions from this thread for ~ilvl 245-250.
At lvl 80 1% crit = 45.91 crit rating. so you would be giving up 91.82 crit rating worth of stats.

In that level of gear 1 crit rating is worth 2.16 AP so that would be an effective loss of 198.3 AP. With 1 AP being equal to 0.93 dps that is a DPS loss of 184.4 DPS.

So lets assume, in that gear you are doing 8k DPS. That would mean you lose 2.3% of your DPS. To make it back you would have to have 2.3% more time DPSing on the boss thanks to the run speed than you would without it. Since the run speed is 15% increased that means you would have to be spending 2.3 / 0.15 = 15% of the fight running between adds doing no damage to make back the DPS you lose when you get there. In short, even on highly mobile fights it probably isnt worth it. Of course if you don't currently have a DPS enchant on your feet you can make back about half the stat loss, but then you would be giving up a run speed enchant so the gain would also be halved making it pretty much the same numbers.
#2506SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Diello
1 AP is .63 DPS at that ilvl, not .93. So it's a ~124.9 DPS loss, ~1.56% in your scenario.

As a wise man once said, There is no right and wrong answer as to whether or not one should spec into IUP.
#2507SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Alyse
It should also be important to note on movement that the 15% increased runspeed does not directly translate to the decrease in runtime*DPS. You can use IT on the run, and is quite optimal if you are switching to a target with no diseases. Furthermore, your pet also makes up a portion of your DPS, and the ghoul can use leap to significantly decrease its run time between mobs.

As Diello stated, there isn't really a right or wrong answer for specing into IUP, but it's important to realize that the calculation for runspeed is not quite as simple as previously stated.
#2508SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sealpup
Re: Improved Unholy Presence
Last week, for experimental purposes, I moved 2 points from Dark Conviction to 2 in Improved Unholy Presence in order to see the differences. For normal modes, the result was rather underwhelming. The fights that need a lot of movements are not difficult ones so far in Icecrown Citadel. Perhaps when hard modes or achievements factors come in. Such as Full House and Putricide's.

In comparison, the 2 points in Morbidity seems to be a much greater investment than Dark Conviction (or Improved Unholy Presence). It has a huge usage return in investment for Valithria, although that fight isn't too difficult, it is also useful for Sindragosa's tombs, and Lich King. For guilds who still do Anub'arak 25 hard mode, it goes without saying that it is priceless there.
#2509SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Unreal54
I was wondering when to use ERW the most effectively for a Reaping spec. At the moment I use it like this for a single target situation (Most of the time at the start of the fight with as many procs running as possible);

IT, PS, BSx2, SS, Garg, HoW, SS, DC, SSx2, ERW, SSx2, BSx2 (Or Pest depending on situation), DCx2

Currently using that method my diseases fall off just before or after the 1st Blood Strike. So Im wondering is this the most effective way of doing it (I.e. Is it possible to use ERW and all abilities afterwards be under the effect of diseases)?

For AoE I follow this rotation;

IT, PS, Pest, DnD, ERW, SSx2, BB/BS, BB/BS, DCx2

Im pretty sure for AoE that is the best use of ERW?

As a side note (Appologise if this has been asked/answered before), being a tank quite often in both 10 & 25man I always apply IT first for FF. Is there a special reason to use PS first for dps (I assume it is because PS is melee based and IT is spell based, therefore perhaps proccing the melee based procs for the following IT)?
Last edited by Unreal54 : 02/08/10 at 2:59 AM.
#2510SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kelben
I was wondering about the optimum glyphs for The Lich King encounter, I initially started with full AOE gylphs, GoD, DnD, and IT. More recently I've been rethinking using the Death and Decay glyph as it just seems to be padding my numbers unnecessarily on phase 1, the trash ghouls die without difficultly and I could put back in GotG (which usually stays full time on the Lich King) Death and Decay is also of limited usage during the following phases. GoD is very useful and seems worth keeping due to the multiple target swaps and the high level of movement during the fight. Any thoughts on this?
#2511SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Medestruit
For single-target boss encounters, generally use the IT-PS(PS-IT, whatever the encounter requires as far as starting the encounter) BSx2-SS-Gargoyle-ERW...setup. The ERW here re-aligns your runes so you won't have to adjust the rotation around the gargoyle. Usually seems to work best, using it almost right away, especially if the fight is long enough where you can use it a 2nd time.
#2512SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Azuma
Originally Posted by Unreal54
As a side note (Appologise if this has been asked/answered before), being a tank quite often in both 10 & 25man I always apply IT first for FF. Is there a special reason to use PS first for dps (I assume it is because PS is melee based and IT is spell based, therefore perhaps proccing the melee based procs for the following IT)?
It is usually used on the run in anyway due to you have to physically get there first, but in situations where you are in melee range first you can PS first to apply the spell dmg debuff and buff not only the IT you will do but the whol raids initial magic dmg.
#2513SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mathrix
Originally Posted by Azuma
It is usually used on the run in anyway due to you have to physically get there first, but in situations where you are in melee range first you can PS first to apply the spell dmg debuff and buff not only the IT you will do but the whol raids initial magic dmg.
The spell damage debuff is actually applied by both diseases now so from a raid perspective you will be buffing them no matter what you do. However personally PS first also applies Rage of Rivendare which is a 10% damage increase for you as well as having Ebon Plaguebringer up for your first Icy Touch.
#2514SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Nyth_
Originally Posted by Unreal54
I was wondering when to use ERW the most effectively for a Reaping spec. At the moment I use it like this for a single target situation (Most of the time at the start of the fight with as many procs running as possible);

IT, PS, BSx2, SS, Garg, HoW, SS, DC, SSx2, ERW, SSx2, BSx2 (Or Pest depending on situation), DCx2

Currently using that method my diseases fall off just before or after the 1st Blood Strike. So Im wondering is this the most effective way of doing it (I.e. Is it possible to use ERW and all abilities afterwards be under the effect of diseases)?

For AoE I follow this rotation;

IT, PS, Pest, DnD, ERW, SSx2, BB/BS, BB/BS, DCx2

Im pretty sure for AoE that is the best use of ERW?

As a side note (Appologise if this has been asked/answered before), being a tank quite often in both 10 & 25man I always apply IT first for FF. Is there a special reason to use PS first for dps (I assume it is because PS is melee based and IT is spell based, therefore perhaps proccing the melee based procs for the following IT)?
Starting with the last first. Basically using PS first is best because you get Rage of Rivendare going straight away. However if you start at range (Marrowgar / Festergut / Rotface / BQL / etc) you best start with icy touch.
Then again for dps this can mess up your disease timers a bit, but I generally time IT to land just before i can put up PS.

As for ERW.

I have recently been experimenting with the disease juggling that Potlol (and a few others) were mentioning a few posts back: http://elitistjerks.com/f72/t72364-u...7/#post1544510

And i have to say im positively surprised by how effective this is. Not only do you get an extra disease tick every 20 seconds. You also pretty much eliminate the bad timing the normal rotation has. In a normal rotation you reapply diseases 0-1 second before it runs out, meaning that you have 5-6 seconds without a single disease tick.
It seems that juggling diseases this way results in a pretty noticeable advantage. Assuming your diseases do about 12% of your total dps, and this technique gives you 2 extra ticks every rotation. That means a 16.67% increase in disease damage or a 2% dps increase.

The juggling either requires you to adjust your rotation, or use the ERW methode that Potlol described. I tried the ERW method since I always found I personally wasn't getting the max out of ERW, and this could be a good way to solve that.

Basically my rotation becomes:
IT>PS>SS>BS>BS> Gargoyle > ERW
SS>SS>DC>SS>DC

After this the runes for IT and PS come up at the exact same time. I'll refresh PS when the timer dips below 3 seconds, and then IT right after that (should have just run out). And the next i'll do it the other way around.

For AoE I tend to save ERW for when it really packs a punch, or when it's really needed. And i think i do it pretty much the same way you do, only i try to use it this way after ERW: BS>SS>BB>SS
That way when the runes come back up the ones for DnD are paired up, and a blood rune comes up first so i can pestilence first (just inside the disease timer).
Last edited by Nyth_ : 02/08/10 at 6:17 AM.
#2515SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Clone
Originally Posted by Unreal54
I was wondering when to use ERW the most effectively for a Reaping spec. At the moment I use it like this for a single target situation (Most of the time at the start of the fight with as many procs running as possible);

IT, PS, BSx2, SS, Garg, HoW, SS, DC, SSx2, ERW, SSx2, BSx2 (Or Pest depending on situation), DCx2

One thing that I noticed right off that bat is that you have 2 Blood strikes at the very end of your rotation.
You should be dumping your excess rp, then refreshing your diseases, then using the blood strikes to refresh desolation and your death runes.

Originally Posted by Nyth_
Starting with the last first. Basically using PS first is best because you get Rage of Rivendare going straight away. However if you start at range (Marrowgar / Festergut / Rotface / BQL / etc) you best start with icy touch.
Then again for dps this can mess up your disease timers a bit, but I generally time IT to land just before i can put up PS.
I disagree with starting your initial rotation with an Icy Touch as this means you have your first application not affected by RoR. In a situation where melee starts out with some runtime to get to the boss, I'll use a DC while I am running. I have yet to see a boss where there is time for 2 GCD's before you can get into position.

#2517SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3mofidik
13% More damage for your casters is really a no brainer, and it should never get you agro over the ranged. Within reasonable situations pestilence is a personal and raid dps increase.

E; my phone horribly fails at qouting.
#2518SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Weidekuh
Originally Posted by Genesus
Normally when the Blood Beasts spawn I cast Pestilence (both 10 and 25) in order to spread the disease and thus enable the casters to bring down the beasts more quickly.
However, I was asked not to do it since it "attracts" the Blood Beasts to the Melee camp (!?).
Is this true? Does Pestilence generate a high amount of threat?
Resistant Skin
The skin of this creature is highly resistant. Damage from area of effect attacks is reduced by 95% and damage from Diseases is reduced by 70%.

Resistant skin + Subversion = there is no way you could pull aggro if someone else is shooting at it.
#2519SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Clone
Originally Posted by Weidekuh
Resistant Skin
The skin of this creature is highly resistant. Damage from area of effect attacks is reduced by 95% and damage from Diseases is reduced by 70%.

Resistant skin + Subversion = there is no way you could pull aggro if someone else is shooting at it.
Exactly...

If you look at every top parse on world or raids / world of logs, you will see that the average dk does 60-90k damage to the blood beasts over the course of the encounter. The damage that we can do to the blood beasts is extremely minimal. But the benefit Ebon Plague provides is very important.

#2524SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noak3
Assuming a reaping build-

If for some reason your desolation drops right before you were about to scourge strike with your death runes, I find that using BS to refresh it then a blood tap/SS is a dps increase. You gain BS + desolation-increased SS, and lose a GCD.

#2529SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Unreal54
So during shitty trash and bosses which are on farm (Marrowgar, Deathwhisper etc...) my fellow DK uses a cast sequence macro as he cant be arsed.

He uses this;

#showtooltip
/startattack
/castsequence reset=2 Plague Strike, Icy Touch, Blood Strike, Blood Strike, Scourge Strike
/use [@pettarget,harm] Claw
/cast !Rune Strike
/script UIErrorsFrame:Hide()

I was just wondering what your thoughts are on it? Is it a serious no no, or could you actually get away with it and do pretty much as the same dps as someone who keybound everything? Ultimately I guess the main factor is latency, but for the purpose of the arguement lets say they are both at the same latency.
#2530SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by Unreal54
So during shitty trash and bosses which are on farm (Marrowgar, Deathwhisper etc...) my fellow DK uses a cast sequence macro as he cant be arsed.

He uses this;

#showtooltip
/startattack
/castsequence reset=2 Plague Strike, Icy Touch, Blood Strike, Blood Strike, Scourge Strike
/use [@pettarget,harm] Claw
/cast !Rune Strike
/script UIErrorsFrame:Hide()

I was just wondering what your thoughts are on it? Is it a serious no no, or could you actually get away with it and do pretty much as the same dps as someone who keybound everything? Ultimately I guess the main factor is latency, but for the purpose of the arguement lets say they are both at the same latency.
The Unholy DPS priority system is not rocket surgery. No, there is no way to get even close to the same DPS using a castsequence-macro, since RP-generation / rune cooldown resets don't follow a perfect order (i.e. you don't always have x RP every y seconds / minutes). Since I figure that most posts asking for castsequence-macros have been shitheaped there actually is a realistic chance that you searched the thread and didn't find anything - so let it be said once and for all: castsequence macros suck and cannot possibly perform even close to good play. If your guildmate can't be bothered to press 5 buttons in an order that even a newborn chimpanzee could manage you might want to look for a new one. Something being "on farm" usually implies that it dies faster, not that it dies slower because people think they can be lazy and / or stupid.
#2531SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Diello
Any DK that can't be bothered to at least use Pestilence on trash to speed things up is a pretty terrible player.
#2532SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Unreal54
/use [@pettarget,harm] Claw
Just a note on this part, while this sort of macro command helps casting pets it does not help melee pets use their ability more often.
#2533SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Shigo
Would using Blood Tap at the end of your first rotation would add or lose dps? I am reaping Unholy spec'd right now. I have only tried it once last night in ICC25 but couldn't tell a difference in the dps. My rotation with it thrown in would go as

PS - IT - BS - BS - SS - DC - BT - SS
SS - BS - SS - DC - BS - PS - IT

I know some people use Blood Tap to recast Boneshield so its a free cast and I haven't done or tried that before because most of the ICC fights you move around so much you can cast it while running.
#2534SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
I've stated a few times that from a logical perspective it's most efficient to use BT to move your death rune SS one rotation up. That way you gain one SS every two minutes instead of 2 BS.

So basically your initial rotation becomes
PS-IT-BS-BT/SS-SS
SS-SS-BS-BS

You continue with
PS-IT-SS-SS
SS-SS-BS-BS

until the BT cooldown is up again and switch back to
PS-IT-SS-SS
SS-SS-BS-BT/SS

and then again until the next BT
PS-IT-SS-BS-BS
SS-SS-SS

This exploits the fact that if you use BT when you just used BS (so that one death rune is on CD) and your second blood rune is up, the death rune CD is reset and you blood rune turns into a death rune, such that you have two death runes to use immediately.

As for Bone Shield: If you cast it right at the start of the encounter, most encounters in ICC are either dead before the 5 minutes have passed or there is some time during the encounter where you can't dps anyways and just recast the shield then.

#2536SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Jareddawg
Originally Posted by Amroo
As I've experienced the gargoyle chooses to melee for the first few seconds after it's been summon if it spawns right on top of the boss. So basically the only way to avoid this is to summon while the boss is being moved as the gargoyle will spawn about where the boss was during summoning. Of course, that's not always possible and I guess it's probably a DPS loss to wait until the boss is being moved instead of summoning with trinket / runeforge procs up.
Gargoyle is one of the only cooldowns available as an unholy death knight which makes it that much more important, and when your main cooldown loses a large amount of damage due to it using its melee attacks on the target, it can be detrimental to your overall dps. Fortunately, there is a way to avoid your gargoyle from being summoned in melee range which allows it to cast freely and reach its fullest potential with no loss to your own personal dps.

When you actually summon the gargoyle, you will notice it is actually flown down about 10-15 yards in front of you. SO, if you were to turn around 180 degrees and summon it then, it will actually fly down a good distance behind you, and since you should be behind the boss in the first place, this puts it at a perfect ranged position far from melee range. I have personally tested this several times and in each case it hasn't used a single melee attack on the target.

#2542SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Malcophant
Just running a quick sim with my gear shows a DPS loss of only 7 DPS switching to 2/3 Morbidity from 2/5 Dark Conviction. This is with 0 RP coming in from AMS/replenishment, so the actual DPS difference will be negligible.
#2543SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Decay
It depends on how much crit you have to begin with. The value of crit tapers off the more of it you have and eventually they will pull even. I prefer morbidity simply due to its utility on aoe fights and high movement fights where I can dump death coils on the move to maximise GCD usage. For crit levels around ~1.1k and down, dark conviction is better on a patchwerk type encounter. All this is of course, assuming no RP, as mentioned above, coming in from revitalise/AMS etc.
#2544SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Unreal54
Just done some quick math, and from what I can work out we will have 201 HR from the BiS list gear, is that right? If so 61/62 HR is a lot to ask from gems/food.
#2545SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rythian
Originally Posted by Unreal54
Just done some quick math, and from what I can work out we will have 201 HR from the BiS list gear, is that right? If so 61/62 HR is a lot to ask from gems/food.
That's not a problem at all. Gemming for hit is really ideal if you think about it. It's the strongest stat you can possibly gem in those slots. Three yellow slots (of which you have plenty) for Rigid Ambers, and you're done. Equipping weaker items with more hit on them only to go around and gem more strength isn't going to be better.
#2546SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Autoband
Originally Posted by Rythian
That's not a problem at all. Gemming for hit is really ideal if you think about it. It's the strongest stat you can possibly gem in those slots. Three yellow slots (of which you have plenty) for Rigid Ambers, and you're done. Equipping weaker items with more hit on them only to go around and gem more strength isn't going to be better.
Gemming hit in itself is never a good thing. As itemlevel goes up, str goes up in a similar fashion. The trade off should never be str v hit (like it is when gemming), but more so hit v haste or hit v exp (for example). Unless you choose low level items because of their hit, then gemming hit isn't a good thing, but an unfortunate necessity.
Last edited by Autoband : 02/09/10 at 11:53 PM.
#2547SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Larisroth
Originally Posted by Autoband
Gemming hit in itself is never a good thing. As itemlevel goes up, str goes up in a similar fashion. The trade off should never be str v hit (like it is when gemming), but more so hit v haste or hit v exp (for example). Unless you choose low level items because of their hit, then gemming hit isn't a good thing, but an unfortunate necessity.
Not exactly, if you're using gemming optimally then most of the time you're actually swapping the non-strength part of an orange gem in a yellow socket from crit or haste to hit rating when you'd still be going for the socket bonus anyway.

#2554SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Medestruit
Originally Posted by Unreal54
Just done some quick math, and from what I can work out we will have 201 HR from the BiS list gear, is that right? If so 61/62 HR is a lot to ask from gems/food.
Are you taking into account the glove and boot enchants? For alliance toons, that will put you at 233 hit(20 from gloves, 12 from boots) which is just above hit cap. Horde will have a bit different gear setup(but that was already known), but even so they can eat hit food to push them up to 273.

Now, doing a quick count, I got 194 hit for the ally setup, and 251 as horde. Ally can grab the boot and glove enchant to bring them up to 226, then use one of their yellow sockets for str/hit to go up to 236. Horde would only need the boot enchant and sit at 263 exactly.
#2555SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Sacros
As others already pointed out, gemming for hit can be done at a loss of 1 crit to 1 hit by using a str/hit orange gem in a yellow socket where it would otherwise be optimal to use a str/crit orange gem. It's just a simple opportunity cost that you can easily calculate by weighing that lost critical strike rating against whatever else you gain by dropping a hit rating piece of gear for something with better stats.

That said, with the current stat weights a horde DK would gain roughly 8 dps using [Lana'thel's Chain of Flagellation] over [Lana'thel's Chain of Flagellation] even on the pre-heroic 25 man best in slot list. Though if expertise turns out to be overvalued for some reason that will obviously not be true. Using Lana'thel's and switching 5 str/crit gems to str/hit, you stay over 8% melee hit and have 3 yellow slots still being used by str/crit gems to spare. This is a good example of why using many hit gems can sometimes be optimal.

In the same vein, using the best in slot list it would seem optimal for a horde DK to use [Winding Sheet] over [Garrosh's Rage], and switch to the precision and icewalker enchants with 3 str/hit gems. The gain would be on the order of 25 dps using the OP's stat weights.
Last edited by Sacros : 02/11/10 at 5:19 AM.
#2556SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Slagg
Tiny Abomination in a Jar again
Since the last patch and the elimination of the range-bug I have tested this weird trinket a bit more and though it is not that good, its not terrible either imo.

Last Saurfang kill I did around 9.5k dps and the proc did 2,8% of my dps.

I am no pro of the statweights but I will give it a try (stats from ilvl264 gear on first page in this thread):

Tiny Abomination in a Jar

2.8% of 9500dps = 266dps
266dps x 1,49(ap) = 396
85hit x 3,92 = 333
Total: 729 (assuming all hit is used)


Deathbringers Will

155arp x 2,49 = 386
600str x 3,03 = 1818
600haste x 2,01 = 1206
600crit x 2,1 = 1260
1818 + 1206 + 1260 / 3 = 1428
1428 x 0,28 = 400
Total: 786


Whispered Fanged Skull Heroic

148crit x 2,1 = 311
1250 x 1 x 0,33 = 412
Total: 723


Whispered Fanged Skull

131crit x 2,1 = 275
1100ap x 1 x 0,33 = 363
Total: 638


Deaths Choice / Verdict

256ap x 1 = 256
450str x 3,03 x 0,33 = 450
Total: 706


DMC: Greatness

90str x 3,03 = 273
300str x 3,03 x 0,33 = 300
Total: 573

---

The thing is it seems like a much better trinket in a fully buffed 25-man raid with Bloodust / Windfury totems etc as you will see more procs.

Am I doing the math terribly wrong or does it really seems like an OK trinket?

#2558SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
The problem with expertise is that it's not trivial to calculate its value and how to interpret it. To explain this, just look at stats like haste, armor penetration or crit. The benefit of haste can be almost perfectly predicted, since it only affects our white ad ghoul damage. Same with armor penetration, although it depends on the different crit rates on your physical attacks compared to your spell attacks, but over time this evens out and the variance isn't that terribly high to begin with. Crit rating is also subject to variance, but since you have a large number of attacks every fight your actual crit rate will converge to your expected crit rate.

The difference to expertise is that you will get the same (expected) damage if you crit every other hit over ten seconds as you would get if you crit every hit for 5 seconds and then don't crit at all for 5 seconds. This is not the case with expertise. Let's assume you attack for one minute and your lack of expertise has your opponent dodge two special attacks. If the first dodge occurs after 15 seconds and the second dodge occurs after 45 seconds, there will be almost loss of damage, since you have a free cd every 30 seconds anyway and the rune grace period often keeps you from desyncing your rune set. Now, in the other scenario your first strike gets dodged and you try to recast it right afterwards and it gets dodged again. The damage loss in this case is tremendous, since you don't have two free gcds in this short period of time, so you are quite likely to overcap RP in the following few seconds making you effectively lose maybe half a DC. Also, if it was a PS or BS your rune pair will be desynced, messing up your rotation, incurring an additional damage loss later on when you try to readjust it.
So, as opposed to most other stats, for expertise it's not only important if the negative events occur, but also when they occur. So, think you have 5.5% expertise and switch to 4.5%. Your chance to be dodged increases by 1%, which certainly incurs some loss (a dodged white attack is always a loss), but in addition the probability of the "catastrophic" event, i.e. you get dodged on two styles in a row, also increases. This implies diminishing returns to expertise (or high returns if you have low expertise), but it also shows that even at high levels the value of expertise depends a lot on how much weight you give reliability.

#2560SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3◊ arison
Modeling expertise isn't really necessary now that we have two nice sims (Kahorie, simcraft). It simply becomes a factor in dps variance which, at least simcraft, shows nicely. It isn't like expertise is the only rng-based stat that affects damage, of course; the difference between a crit SS and non-crit SS is quite a bit, too. It all amortizes over a fight.

The problem with any talk of rotations is that your rotation is always going to get screwed up and weird in most any fight. Even Saurfang, where you may not have a blood rune available and instead need to Rune Tap -- there you go, runes out of sync. Not to mention the movement or target switching fights that fill ICC. Rotations are a myth; they exist in the abstract as nice ways to learn but in the real world, it's priority all the way.

And that's the kicker -- priority makes expertise less valuable. You would never SS without diseases up, but a rotation may have you do just that if you get back-to-back dodges. In the real world, you'd move on to refreshing diseases etc instead. It definitely is true that lost GCDs can hurt when it comes to extra sources of RP (which ICC is replete with -- many fights where AMS is great as well as revitalize, of course) but ultimately you are trading other stats which make up for it. It's all well and good to say "wow you missed half a DC, that's 2k damage amortized over the whole fight" but the 50 armpen or str you picked up in exchange is also working for you throughout the fight as well. This is simulation territory; intuition and back-of-the-envelope only work so well. Currently the stat weights are based on a rotation system rather than priority and so they are valued pretty highly compared to priority-based simulation (which is the simcraft default).

There also is room for personal preference; it really does suck to have to repeat attacks and you definitely feel it during fights. It definitely is good to have some expertise but perfectly hitting cap isn't necessary. Lost GCDs do get made up for here and there so really they are just pushed back than lost forever, but if your expertise (or hit) is so low that you do permanently lose GCDs then it is a bigger issue.

Point for point, expertise and hit give you the same reduction in chance for an attack to fail, but hit affects more abilities and so it is more valuable. 32.79 hit rating is one percent of hit; 8.2 expertise rating gives 1 expertise, so 32.8 expertise rating is needed for 4 expertise which is 1% less attack failure (from behind only, of course). A big part of this, too, is a failed DC (which only uses hit) costs more than a failed strike (which you can retry since you get the runes refunded immediately). Miss that DC and 40RP is gone forever.
#2561SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Pyrius
That's incorrect. It stacks.

In case you doubt:

# Unholy Blight: This talent has been redesigned. It no longer deals damage to nearby targets. Instead, when you deal damage with Death Coil, the target will take periodic damage for 10 seconds equal to 20% of the damage done by Death Coil. This damage accumulates in the same way as Ignite and Deep Wounds.
It has since been scaled back to 10% but the mechanic is the same.

#2564SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by arison
Stuff...
My post was only to illustrate that expertise becomes more valuable the less you have of it. At no point did I try to imply that everyone should start gemming it right now. It's just the point, that it's probably not bad to have at least somewhere around 15 expertise, so that your rotation doesn't get reliably screwed up. Of course is strength and armor penetration at high levels significantly better, but people should never forget the trade-off between consistent damage and a bit more, but volatile damage.
Also the comparison with crit you made is slightly incorrect. If crit would work for Unholy DKs like expertise it would mean that if you have one non-crit you would still get the same damage as if you had a crit, but if you had two non-crits in a row, you'd die (exaggerating a bit, here). For crit it doesn't matter if you crit 20 SS in the first two minutes and then none or if you crit 20 SS over the course of four minutes (except possibly for procs and such that might or might not be up).
Also, it doesn't matter if you have a rotation or priority system. A rotation that is so strict it makes you SS if you have no diseases up is not a rotation, it is idiocy. And in a priority system it sucks as much as in a rotation if your rune pairs are desynced.

As I've written, expertise is certainly not the best stat an Unholy DK can get (and only gets worse by comparison if you have more than one target) and even at 0 expertise it's probably (certainly) better to eat strength food and enchant AP / Hit / Strength on gloves than expertise, but people should still aim in their gearing for at least some expertise, simply due to the way our resource system works.

It is suspected that Blood will pull ahead at some point, because it scales better with ARP, and ARP is such an amazing stat that will be abundant on 277 gear. That said, Unholy is more or less equal to Blood on tank and spank fights right now, and pulls ahead on any fight with adds, AOE or where AMS can be used for lots of RP intake. That said, unholy will stay close and doesn't have the stupid >75% hp requirement to do max dps.

#2632SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Neddie
Originally Posted by Shrakz
On the following table, the TOP 20 DPS of all active melee DPS specs on WoL are shown for Festergut 25 man (No Subtlety rogues at all):

[snip]

As you can see in the table, Ferals are about 2% higher than where they should be.
Rets are at a good place.
Arms warriors, enhancement shamans and blood DKs are about 6% too low.
Fury warriors are pretty high (endless rage situation with ICC gear)
Frost DKs are by far the worst in terms of melee DPS output.
I'm not sure this is a fair way to compare classes and specs. Some players may choose their spec based on it being their favorite playstyle or because they think they can get the most DPS out of it, others will do it to make sure the raid has all the necessary buffs. It's fair to compare say Balance and Feral or Elemental and Enhancement because the gear and playstyle are so different, but for a class with multiple melee DPS specs where one is acknowledged to be better, either because of the buffs it brings, or because it has been shown to do the best damage, more of the best geared DKs will be playing that spec. It's possible that the top-rated frost DPS DKs are the 2nd best geared DKS DK in a guild, and end up speccing frost to provide the raid with imp. icy talons. Similarly, arms may only be slightly behind fury, but it's enough of a difference that almost every DPS warrior goes fury if given the chance, but sometimes the less well geared ones are asked to spec arms to provide the MS debuff and trauma for the ferals.

In any case, it does look like warriors and druids are doing very well, paladins are about right, DKs are a bit low (and frost needs serious work) and shamans are in horrible shape.
#2633SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Shrakz
Originally Posted by Neddie
I'm not sure this is a fair way to compare classes and specs.
It wasn't my intention to compare the classes/specs and say that all warriors should spec Fury or all DKs should spec Unholy because the specs put out the highest DPS. I just thought it would be interresting to look at how the melee specs perform on tank and spank fights given the current level of gear, since I haven't found any similar post elsewhere.

For example, in our raids, we had an arms warrior for the 4% damage buff and 2x mutilate rogues for most of the fights. At some point the warrior switched to Fury and one of the rogues went combat to provide the 4% buff himself since it would most probably yield in a higher raid DPS. A chart like this one can help maximize the raid DPS if your players are willing to play another spec (and that they play the other spec as good as their main one).

As for Unholy DKs, even if we are a bit lower than some specs on pure single target tank and spank fights, and as it was stated by another poster: we still do decent single target damage and our great survivability (that cannot be measured by numbers in a chart similar to this one) allows us to have higher dps uptime on some fights (Sindragosa for example).
#2634SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Savetheday
Originally Posted by Clone
This was posted a few pages back...but I'll post my usual opening.

PS, IT, BS, BS, SS, Garg, ERW, SS, SS, DC, SS, DC, DC
I found that alternating the last SS with a DC will allow for 1 additional dc in the opening rotation.

I actually prefer the PS, IT. BS, SS, BT> SS(cancel blood tap), Garg ERW, SS SS DC BS BS DC DC. If you're using GoD the 3rd BS should be a pestilence.

Basically this allows for SS to move up in your rotation, and fitting in an extra BS into your initial rotation. If you're lusting early you'll be using an ironshield potion for your first gargoyle more then likely, and if the fight lasts long enough you'll speed pot the 2nd.(if not I would just aim for speed potting with Fallen Crusader and another proc being up)

To answer the rest of the question AoD should be used pre-pull still, and ERW best during blood lust or beginning when all your internal/procs are up.

I swear this has been answered before but I can't seem to find it. How do people reliably sync up their blood runes with the spawning of the blood beasts on Saurfang? With us attempting heroic mode in the near future I'd like to get this down consistently instead of throwing my runes out of sync or delaying my runes.

Any insight would be appreciated.
I noticed pestilencing just after they come up usually syncs my blood runes with their spawn timer. I'm not sure if the spawn timer is the same for heroic but I never actually had a problem syncing it if I was using GoD.(which is a dps gain if you're going to consistently spread EPB to the adds.)
#2635SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Neddie
Originally Posted by Shrakz
I just thought it would be interresting to look at how the melee specs perform on tank and spank fights given the current level of gear, since I haven't found any similar post elsewhere.
Ok, but you have to realize that there's a selection bias in your data. You're comparing apples to oranges.

Let's say there's a raid group with 2 DPS warriors: Albert and Bethie. Albert does 10k DPS as fury, Bethie does 9.5k DPS as fury, assuming all standard buffs/debuffs are present. Because your raid leader wants the 4% damage debuff, she asks Bethie to spec arms. It makes the most sense to do this because you know Arms does less damage than Fury, so you as the warrior doing less damage to provide the buffs. As Arms, Bethie does 9.4k DPS, only losing 100 DPS over her fury spec. However, since she's now the top arms warrior in damage, she shows up in your chart as 9.4k DPS whereas Albert shows up at 10k DPS. It looks like arms is 600 DPS worse than fury, but in reality it's that the best / best geared warriors are speccing fury for the DPS, and the second best / second best geared warriors are speccing arms for the buffs / debuffs.

Getting rid of this selection bias would be really hard. I'm not saying your data is useless, just that it should be taken with a grain of salt. What you're saying isn't that a typical DK specced into frost will do 80% of a typical combat rogue, but rather that the best DKs who end up raiding as frost, whether from personal preference or because they had to spec frost to provide a necessary buff, end up doing 80% of the damage of the best combat rogues.
#2636SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Amroo
Originally Posted by Neddie
Ok, but you have to realize that there's a selection bias in your data. You're comparing apples to oranges.
Considering the sheer number of logs, selection bias isn't actually an issue. It would be, if we were comparing averages, but since he is only looking at the top parses of each distribution, it's very likely (pretty much certain) that these are exclusively well geared players who know what they are doing. I doubt there will be a significant difference in average gear level or skill of the top 20 players in each spec / class.
That's not saying that there is a point to such a comparison (which I doubt), just that selection bias really isn't the issue.

Your second point about the interpretation of the data is still true, though. It doesn't mean that the average combat rogue is 2k DPS ahead of the average Unholy DK (since we are not compating averages), just that the possible DPS of a combat rogue is 2k DPS ahead.
Last edited by Amroo : 02/17/10 at 9:53 PM.
#2637SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		cpand671
Gargoyle
I think the Gargoyle section should be updated. There was a post awhile back talking about how gargoyles would randomly melee when spawned on top of bosses/mobs. The remedy to this is to spin 180 degrees when your GCD timer resets and summon the gargoyle. Although it does not always prevent melees I've found it to be pretty successful. I have gone from 14% gargoyle melee damage on Saurfang to 4.7% and from 18% on Festergut to 2.5%. The reason this works is because the gargoyle is spawned away from the boss when you do a 180, thus preventing the melees. I have to watch more carefully to see what the gargoyle is doing on Festergut to still get melees and will update accordingly.

World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis Saurfang

World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis Festergut
Last edited by cpand671 : 02/19/10 at 11:59 AM.

I think the Gargoyle section should be updated. There was a post awhile back talking about how gargoyles would randomly melee when spawned on top of bosses/mobs. The remedy to this is to spin 180 degrees when your GCD timer resets and summon the gargoyle. Although it does not always prevent melees I've found it to be pretty successful. World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis Saurfang

World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis Festergut
Festergut has a larger hit box and since you usually stand very close for the spores, doing a half turn might not always be enough to spawn the gargoyle outside melee range. Just try to move to maximum hit range before turning and summoning and the problem should be solved as the gargoyle will spawn even further out.
#2639SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kulgoss

#2642SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Amroo
Originally Posted by cpand671
Would moving to max melee range if he has a big hit box interfere with the throwup debuff?
No, you just stand very tight together that everyone including tanks gets the shadow protection debuff. Moving to max melee range doesn't make you a valid target vor Vile Gas.

Originally Posted by Complicated
I've been trying the spinning Garg summon and found it pretty succesfull, this would actually make a swing-timer for Death Knights usefull as you don't wanna miss out on a ~5k melee swing.
It's not even that much of an issue, since if you had a swing during the time you face away from the boss you will instantly swing as soon as you face him again. So even if you don't track your white hits at all your expected loss is just about a quarter of a white hit (assuming 3 second swing timer and not facing the boss for 1.5 seconds). It would probably be more of a loss if you wait for the swing before you turn and delay runes that way. As soon as one gets really good at twisting such that the non-facing time is less than a second, there is virtually no loss at all.

About bosses like Sindragosa or Marrowgar it's very important to note that you really must stand at maximum hit box when twisting. If you don't, even if your summoned gargoyle looks like it's very far away from the boss it might still be within melee range (and start meleeing) due to the way the hit box on these bosses exceeds the physical model by a lot.
Last edited by Amroo : 02/19/10 at 1:21 PM.

Would the fly in be too long and therefore a dps loss, or ensure 100% that it will always fly to max melee range and cast? What do you guys think?

#2645SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3loranta
Glyph of PS vs. Glyph of DD
Is there any reason that one might not want to consider using Glyph of PS over Glyph of DD? I saw some figs for DC in earlier postings on sims, but did not see anything on PS for the same sims. GoDD has a 15% bonus for DC, and GoPS does 20% bonus damage for PS.

Will GoPS also put bonus dmg on the resulting Blood Plague? I presume not. Likewise, with Unholy Blight. Just want to clarify if these might be factors as well.

I've looked through a good part of the discussion and did not see this addressed, but there is so much, so forgive me if it has. I am a bit new a theorycrafting as well.

This would be for my unholy DK, currently 2H, considering trying DW if the opportunity arises.
#2646SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		cpand671
Originally Posted by loranta
Is there any reason that one might not want to consider using Glyph of PS over Glyph of DD? I saw some figs for DC in earlier postings on sims, but did not see anything on PS for the same sims. GoDD has a 15% bonus for DC, and GoPS does 20% bonus damage for PS.

I've looked through a good part of the discussion and did not see this addressed, but there is so much, so forgive me if it has. I am a bit new a theorycrafting as well.

This would be for my unholy DK, currently 2H, considering trying DW if the opportunity arises.
Consider your Plague Strike averaging for 3,500 non-crit and your Death Coil averaging for 4,500 non-crit. You use 1 Plague Strike in a 20 second rotation, and you use Death Coil 3-4 times in a rotation. Without even having to do math you should already see that Death Coil is going to give you more benefit with Dark Death than Plague Strike with its respective glyph, but for math's sake:

3,500 Plague Strike + Glyph = 4,200

4,500 Death Coil + Glyph = 5,175

You are gaining 700 damage per rotation with the Plague Strike glyph and you are gaining 2,025-2,700 damage with the Dark Death glyph. I'm also taking into account that there is 0/3 Morbidity and it is also ignoring Unholy Blight, so you would be gaining even more damage if you happened to be specialized into them (Blight a given).

Originally Posted by loranta
Will GoPS also put bonus dmg on the resulting Blood Plague? I presume not. Likewise, with Unholy Blight. Just want to clarify if these might be factors as well.
Blood Plague is not affected by Glyph of Plague Strike.

#2648SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Smutt
Seems like a no brainer question, but for as long as I have played my DK I always refreshed my diseases before they fell off (under 1 sec left on the duration). Recently I have been trying to get as many SS in as possible and have been letting my diseases fall off and getting in that extra SS and then reapplying diseases when the applicable runes come off cd. Usually diseases are only off for a split second and get refreshed asap never using blood strike with no disease up. Is there any math or theorycrafting to say its a dps increase (or decrease) to let diseases fall for a split second in order to get an extra SS, or is it better to keep 100% uptime and refresh before they fall off?

Relevant change from PTR:

Scourge Strike: Now deals 70% weapon damage, plus 12% of physical damage done as shadow damage for each of the death knight's diseases on the target.

Newest Buffs on PTR
Unholy

Scourge Strike: Now deals 70% weapon damage, plus 12% of physical damage done as shadow damage for each of the death knight's diseases on the target. The net result should be larger strikes with no diseases present, while maximum damage with all diseases applied to the target should stay the same.

#2655SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3nhlkdog411
You're counting outbreak in the first and not in the second...and the second part is additive not multiplicative....its more along the lines of (50%+4%(2hand spec))*1.2 (outbreak) + 75% = 113.4% vs. [(70%+4%)*1.2] + 36% = 120%...my math might not be perfect here but its certainly not a nerf as far as i can tell.
#2656SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
You all are completely ignoring the fact that the magical disease based damage is completely dependent on the physical damage. Thus even though the disease modifier was cut in half, the damage of the magical strike was not reduced by the same propotion because the physical damage increased.

To explain:

Let's say, currently, the physical portion of your SS hits for 6600, while the shadow portion hits for 6750. Those are numbers drawn from a random log, and they're pretty typical. That average SS hit for 13,350.

If the physical damage is increased by 40% (50% -> 70% base), then it will hit for 9240. Now, if the shadow portion was hitting for 103% (6750/6600) of the physical potion, but is reduced by 48% (25%/disease to 12%/disease), then ti will be hitting for 49% (1.03 x .48) of the physical strike, for a magical damage of 4528 (9240 x .48). That average SS hit is then 13,767.

Yes, I ignored the flat damage portion, which will then lower the latter SS's damage slightly, thus making them basically even. The point is, it's hardly any difference.
#2657SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Shanoa
Thinking about it, ARP would just become even stronger for us, since it affects only the physical damage, and it got buffed, thus resulting in a higher SS damage.
#2658SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3nhlkdog411
Originally Posted by Consider
You all are completely ignoring the fact that the magical disease based damage is completely dependent on the physical damage. Thus even though the disease modifier was cut in half, the damage of the magical strike was not reduced by the same propotion because the physical damage increased.

To explain:

Let's say, currently, the physical portion of your SS hits for 6600, while the shadow portion hits for 6750. Those are numbers drawn from a random log, and they're pretty typical. That average SS hit for 13,350.

If the physical damage is increased by 40% (50% -> 70% base), then it will hit for 9240. Now, if the shadow portion was hitting for 103% (6750/6600) of the physical potion, but is reduced by 48% (25%/disease to 12%/disease), then ti will be hitting for 49% (1.03 x .48) of the physical strike, for a magical damage of 4528 (9240 x .48). That average SS hit is then 13,767.

Yes, I ignored the flat damage portion, which will then lower the latter SS's damage slightly, thus making the basically even. The point is, it's hardly any difference.
Yeah that's basically what I was trying to get across with my extremely quickly done math that ignored a lot of the modifiers...they're aiming to have the same pve dmg with better pvp dmg.
#2659SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Scourge Strike was:

(0.6D + 480)(1 + 0.75 * 1.43)

where 1.43 is as far as I know the double-dip multiplier for the shadow portion

New Scourge Strike (static damage stays the same):

(0.84D + 480) * (1 + 0.36 * 1.43)

Then

1.24D + 995 ? 1.27 D + 727

With pre-Cataclysm gear that seems to be a (slight) nerf, if they shift the static damage slightly upwards to account for the smaller multiplier, it's about equal.

Originally Posted by Shanoa
Thinking about it, ARP would just become even stronger for us, since it affects only the physical damage, and it got buffed, thus resulting in a higher SS damage.
No, it doesn't work like that. Right now 100% of SS profits from ArP. After patch 100% of SS will profit from ArP. If SS hits the same, there is no change.
#2660SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3

Old SS was 50% weapon Damage as physical
New SS is 70% of weapon Damage as physical

This will equate to a buff to ArP stat weight since even more of our damage is counted as physical and even less as shadow.

Sounds like this is the mid-season PvP buff we've been expecting since DKs run into disease cleansing problems in arenas.
